head_templates.name: grc-noun
head_templates.expansion: ἄνθρωπος • (ánthrōpos) m or f (genitive ἀνθρώπου); second declension

etymology_text:
First attested in Hellenic as Mycenaean Greek 𐀀𐀵𐀫𐀦 (a-to-ro-qo), of uncertain origin. Scholars used to consider it to be a compound from ἀνήρ (anḗr, “man”) and ὤψ (ṓps, “face, appearance, look”): thus, "he who looks like a man". However, a δ (d) would be expected to develop by epenthesis, as in the genitive ἀνδρός (andrós), yielding *ἀνδρωπος (*andrōpos). Rosén defends this etymology, positing that the original laryngeal *h₃ in the root for ὤψ (ṓps) (from Proto-Indo-European *h₃ókʷs) changed the δ to its aspirated counterpart θ even across the intervening ρ.
Beekes argues that since no convincing Indo-European etymology has been found, the word is probably of Pre-Greek origin; he connects the word with the word δρώψ (drṓps, “man”). According to Beekes (2009:xxix), "Shift of aspiration is found in some cases: θριγκός / τριγχός, ἀθραγένη / ἀνδράχνη".
Garnier proposes a derivation from Proto-Indo-European *n̥dʰéreh₃kʷós (“that which is below”) (from *(H)n̥dʰér + *-h₃kʷ-o-), hence "earthly, human", for this compare with Proto-Indo-European *dʰéǵʰōm (“earth”) whence Latin homō, Old Lithuanian žmuõ (“man”), Old English guma (“man”).
The word is treated in Plato's Cratylus.

glosses: human being, person (as differentiated from gods, beasts, etc.); man, woman

categories.name: Ancient Greek masculine nouns in the second declension

raw_glosses: (sometimes in the plural) all human beings, mankind

etymology_text: From Proto-Hellenic *lógos, from Proto-Indo-European *leǵ- (“to collect (words)”). See also λέγω (légō, “to reckon, say”).

glosses: that which is said: word, sentence, speech, story, debate, utterance, argument

categories.name: Ancient Greek second-declension nouns without gender specified

glosses: that which is thought: reason, consideration, computation, reckoning

examples.text: (1) Ἐν ἀρχῇ ἦν ὁ λόγος, καὶ ὁ λόγος ἦν πρὸς τὸν θεόν, καὶ θεὸς ἦν ὁ λόγος. … (14) Καὶ ὁ λόγος σὰρξ ἐγένετο καὶ ἐσκήνωσεν ἐν ἡμῖν, καὶ ἐθεασάμεθα τὴν δόξαν αὐτοῦ, δόξαν ὡς μονογενοῦς παρὰ πατρός, πλήρης χάριτος καὶ ἀληθείας.
examples.ref: Gospel of John, 1:1 (Greek New Testament, KJV translation)
examples.english: (1) In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. … (14) And the Word became flesh, and dwelt among us, and we saw His glory, glory as of the only begotten from the Father, full of grace and truth.
examples.translation: (1) In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. … (14) And the Word became flesh, and dwelt among us, and we saw His glory, glory as of the only begotten from the Father, full of grace and truth.

raw_glosses: (theology) the word or wisdom of God, identified with Jesus in the New Testament, by whom the world was created; God the Son
glosses: the word or wisdom of God, identified with Jesus in the New Testament, by whom the world was created; God the Son

etymology_text: Related to ἐρεείνω (ereeínō, “to ask”), ἔρομαι (éromai, “to ask”) (which it replaced in Attic), ἐρευνάω (ereunáō, “to search, inquire”), of uncertain origin. The hypothetical reconstructed root, Proto-Indo-European *h₁rew- (“to search, inquire”), appears to be related to Icelandic raun (“trial, test”) and Old Armenian որոնեմ (oronem, “to seek, search for”) (though there exist phonetic issues with the Armenian).

etymology_templates.name: cog
etymology_templates.expansion: Old Armenian որոնեմ (oronem, “to seek, search for”)
